description:
From Middle English waften, of uncertain origin. Possibly from unattested Old English *wafettan, from wafian (“to wave”) +‎ -ettan, or perhaps borrowed from Middle Dutch wachten (“to guard, provide for”).
See also German wabern (“to waft”), Faroese veiftra (“to wave”) and Icelandic váfa (“to fluctuate, waver, doubt”).

examples: It lay before him white and ghaistly, with mist blowing in wafts across it and a slow swaying of the tides.

entries.meaning: Something (such as an odor or perfume) that is carried through the air.
(nautical) A flag used to indicate wind direction or, with a knot tied in the center, as a signal; a waif, a wheft.

verbs.description: waft (third-person singular simple present wafts, present participle wafting, simple past and past participle wafted)

entries.meaning: (ergative) To (cause to) float easily or gently through the air.
examples: A breeze came in through the open window and wafted her sensuous perfume into my eager nostrils.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be moved, or to pass, on a buoyant medium; to float.
examples: Unhappy Aureng-Zebe is in disgrace; / And your Morat, proclaimed the successor, / Is called, to awe the city with his power. / Those trumpets his triumphant entry tell, / And now the shouts waft near the citadel.

entries.meaning: To give notice to by waving something; to wave the hand to; to beckon.
